reviewText:
Several things to take note of:
The game language is initially set to Japanese. This can be set to English in the options menu.
The devs went out of their way to set initial language to English in an update! How nice.

This game is certainly an anamoly. It's a 3D bullet hell versus game with, uh, crustaceans as the combatants. I'm jumping on reviewing this because I was really pleasantly surprised.

The devs have it down to a point in the description; these are creatures we eat so casually, yet underwater, they are some of the most inclined to fight with one another over mates within their own species, even for food amongst other crustacean species. I mean, look up a crab and lobster fighting. It's some interesting stuff.

And I believe that is perfectly captured in this game. Just with the addition of lasers and bullets being shot out of their eyes and energy claw attacks and what not. I can see that there was love put into this thing; the Snow Crab, for instance, can only move forward" by turning sideways first.

I really wouldn't dismiss this as one of those one-off funny games just because of that
recommended: there is some depth and rhyme and reason to it
hoursPlayed: which I will do my best to describe.\n\nA big part of the game is the fact that a majority of the crustacean fighters can sustain limb damage. Using the example of the Snow Crab once more
voteText: for instance
helpfulPercent: you can lose all of your legs and thus
votesHelpful: experience a reduction in speed. The only way to circumvent this is to spend accumulated meter points to shed your skin and gain all your limbs back. During this maneuver
votesTotal: you're very vulnerable upon coming back anew. You can also self-mutilate yourself while you attack
commentsCount: to make your hitbox smaller or for some mad hit and run tactics.\n\nAnother feature of the game is the weakpoints of each of the fighters. Take the Hermit Crab
column16: for instance. It cannot be damaged at all if hit in the shell they hide in. It can be broken
column17: but you better take care of the thing before it finds another shell (think Cody's knife from Street Fighter). Thus
column18: knowing your crustacean match-ups will lead you to AQUATIC VICTORY.\n\nEach arthopod also possesses a differing movesets
column19: each having unique ranged and melee attacks along with charged attacks that take meter to use. Meter is accumulated by hitting and by getting hit. Careful management of meter is central in this game
column21: as you'll be a sitting duck if you lose your limbs and don't have the meter to regenerate.\n\nAfter fights you also get aquarium parts
column22: which are not only for asthetic
column23: but can also help you in upcoming fights. Starfish
column25: spin around like a damn rapid spin Staryu to do some chip damage. Very nice touch
column26: although I never really touched this feature.\n\nThe music is also gloriously manic
column28: honestly. You can go from some smooth jazz and traditional Japanese instrumentation as you shoot lobster lazers at barnacles to some Japanese vocal rock when you fight some of the later opponents in the "story mode". It's great.\n\nThe game is a bit lacking in giving a tutorial
column29: but with Assassin's Creed-esque button prompts that tell you what each button does when you press it
column30: which can be turned off at any point
column31: it should be more than enough. The controls in of themselves can be a bit finicky at first
column33: especially with the crabs in particular that can't conventionally move forwards
column34: but it's something that I got used to
column35: especially after taking note of things such as water current affecting your movement.\n\nI can heartily recommend this game as both a novelty and as something functional and fun. Definitely something to laugh with your friends about. There's online multiplayer too
column36: which I haven't delved into myself. If you're not sold and the mechanics don't interest you
column38: I'd say to wait for a bigger price drop
column39: but I'm having a lot of fun with this thing myself
column40: and it should keep you busy for a while with several difficulties

reviewText:
Not often is there a game that can tickle your funny bone at the same time as being enjoyable.
-----------PROS:
-Fast paced action
-Interesting subject matter and background story
-Beautiful art (Graphical design dated to circa 2008)
-Ability to make your own maps

---------CONS:
-Repetitive gameplay
-Attacks feel weak
-Issue with balance of characters

----------NEUTRAL:
-Controls take some getting used to

REVIEW:
Gameplay depth is limited, and fitting to experience this game in short bursts. After 1-2 hours most of the essential dynamics will be evident, and gameplay becomes repetitive. After several matches, the ideal combination of (characters and items) becomes evident. Subsequently, each match will resemble the prior after you have figured out the correct mix.

Background story and subject matter are unique, interesting and humorous. I will not go in-depth into this feature as to avoid spoilers. The basic gist regards a new technology which allows humans to use sections of the oceans as aquariums. As a result, crustaceans evolve into bad-♥♥♥ laser shooting beings which, for some reason still cant figure out how to stand up right. The graphics, although not perfect, do justice to the unique story and subject matter with an appropriate tone and style.

Overall, characters are well balanced, each with particular strengths and weaknesses. These traits usually balance each other out. However, in the case of the Barnacle, it's increased firepower overcompensates for its reduced mobility; which makes it an overpowered class.

Aiding replayability, the game contains a Create a map" mode where you can customize your aquarium
date: and choosing the location for flora and fauna. The animals will aid you during battle by shielding you
hoursPlayed: etc. This adds some depth to the gameplay
voteText: as you can use the (money/points/credits) you gain on each match to purchase more offensive or defensive assistance.\n\nThis is not a game with a long shelf life
helpfulPercent: but it is a fun game as you discover the different dynamics
votesTotal: offensive and  defensive mechanisms and their optimized combinations.\n\nAs a final verdict I give it 7/10. In all truth you wont play this every day but during the time that it is played it is very fun and has about the same value as a movie. This is a sometimes food but a good sometimes food it is. Overall
votesFunny: this is a fun little game that will set you about the price of a movie ticket and will entertain you for at least as long. Some games are better enjoyed in small doses

reviewText:
Holy ♥♥♥♥.
This game is something else.

You'll spend about 30-45 minutes trying to figure out how to move your crustacean in as straight a line as possible, to find you're still clueless as to what the other controls actually do. The game comes with labels of what button does what, at least, but no explanation of mechanics behind them. It gets worse. Don't jump straight into campaign whatever you do, practise on freemode to learn the basics, because trust me:

All ♥♥♥♥ing hell breaks loose.
Pitted against my first opponent, it becomes intense VERY fast when lasers shoot out of your enemies crevices in all directions, performing nautical manuevers on a dogfighting equivalent, as I struggled to barely hobble my lobster in its general direction. And then the ♥♥♥♥ing scenery starts attacking you.

You are given literally no explanation of why anything happens in this game, you aren't told why you have the ability to fling your legs at the enemy, or what the control function actually does, or what POW even stands for, I don't even know at this point what 'Oxygen' or 'Organic matter' does in the game.

Some things you that may help you first off;
~ Holding down 'C' then pressing either Z or X detaches your melee and ranged limbs. HOWEVER, what the game doesn't explain is that they can still function and be used remotely, and have strategic uses.
~ The scenery, as I mentioned earlier, can be your ally. The coral, leeches, sea slugs, starfish, those weird giant shrimp things, can be recruited to your team by holding 'C' in their vicinity and will proceed to attack your opponent. This can even be used to recruit your enemy's following.
~ During the campaign, you unlock more placeable scenery, which can be added to your side of the Aquarium by pressing space and entering the Aquarium editor. This is extremely useful in the later stages of the campaign, otherwise you'll get your ♥♥♥ handed to you by that ♥♥♥♥ing CPU Lobster.

Other than that, each Crustacean has their own movement and abilities you must learn in order to fight effectively, although this can be done in practise mode.

All in all, the game has alien controls that you'll be forced to become accustom to, almost no explanation of mechanics, and Crab claws that produce laser swords.

It's chaos in it's most beautiful and Crusty form. Buy the game, become the Crab King.

reviewText:
Summary:

Look, there's some cool ideas under the surface here and some off humor here, but the problem? 2 Major ones: controls and information. The game does not give you the controls necessary to take advantage of the cool limb system and the regrowing mechanics, and that kills the game's playability all over the place. I'm really attempting to understand why THIS control system was chosen, because it goes against simple game design elements. The game gives you a bunch of information on oxygen and what not....and you have no idea what that does. Honestly, in the end, the game works against itself: the cool concepts can't exactly overshadow the huge issues regarding the controls, and legimately makes me wonder how they were testing the game in question, because I don't see anyway that made any logical sense.

Video Gameplay and Impressions: http://youtu.be/OyVl3TkbRYU

Lists:

+:
I like the limb system and while I do wish that there was a bit more to it, there's some strategy here and a cool system that can be taken advantage of.
The weird humor. It's pretending to be badly translated, but it's hilarious none the less. Poseidon Potatos. That is all.
If you like crabs, this game is your friend. Do like the difference in every character on the surface. Some seem over powered.
-:
Controls, Controls, Controls. Not only are the controls bad, but even when you get a hold of it, it does not give you the precision that you need to take advantage of those elements.
Did I mention the controls? The controls. I can't emphasize this enough: the controls.
The game has a bunch of information on screen that it never explains, and honestly I can't figure out exactly what that DOES.
Ranged attacks >>>>>> melee attacks due to homing and the control system (yes I'm hammering home on this). This is particularly a problem when one character has a huge advantage when it comes to ranged.
The UI is pretty bad. It looks like it was an after thought.
The colors underwater can really hurt the game in question as it can be really hard to see what's going on.
The camera hates you. It's part of the controls, and it's bad, but the camera is a bad design decision all around.
The WTF factor doesn't overshadow the rest of the problems. I mean, WTF can be great and all, but Let's not joke about the fact that a WTF game should still be good (Octodad is a great example).

reviewText:
Once you get past the bizarre setup of this game, it actually becomes... well, probably more bizarre, but there's a surprising amount of depth to this laser-crab-battle simulator.

The game essentially plays as a vs brawler where you're each a boss from a bullet hell game.  Each crustacean comes with its own array of attack patterns, and each one is wholly unique to that creature.  As a match starts up, you can try to leverage an environmental advantage by taking control of nearby wildlife which act as fodder turrets and enemies to bog down your opponent, or you can drive headlong at the other guy, batting away bullets with your melee attacks and try to drive a plasma-sheathed antennae into their heart.  You can even tear off your own limbs and have them swarm the opponent, surround you as a really weird sort of defensive array, or lie in wait as a trap.  Every creature has 3 levels of super attacks as well, which get incredibly bullet-hellish and are increasingly bizarre (one late unlock character separates into a dozen pieces which grow lightsaber arms and home menacingly toward the enemy).  It's all surprisingly compelling once you begin to open up the game, and the skill ceiling is high.  And there is that immense weirdness which is a draw all on its own.

I say that there's a depth to the game, and that's true, but sadly there isn't a huge amount of breadth.  There isn't much content past a short story mode (which you'll be playing through several times to unlock characters) and an even shorter bonus story mode of only two stages that act as a sort of epilogue, and behind which are hidden the final two unlockable characters.  Speaking of characters, there are only ten, and while they encompass a huge amount of variety themselves (one can burrow, one can only shoot in the direction it's facing, one moves by reproducing and spawning copies of itself, etc etc), the low number of characters means you'll see most of what the game has to offer long before hitting that aforementioned high skill ceiling.  This means that you'll more than likely get bored and move on before mastering all the game's tricks and strategies.  Additionally, four of the characters are bosses themselves, and are intentionally cranked up to 11 and are pretty OP, meaning that only 6 of the characters are seriously playable if you were to somehow convince a friend to get in on some laser crab action (the game touts online and local vs modes).

Anyway, this is a way more comprehensive and serious review than the game probably demands, but I feel like I can't talk to anyone in real life about Neo Aquarium so I'm casting my opinions of the game to the sea, so to speak. Pick this up if you were wooed by the game's strangeness, are super into spiny lobsters, or if you want to experience a wholly unique and difficult to wrangle battle game.

reviewText:
9/10

Neo Aquarium may not have much in terms of fancy graphics, but it makes up for it in details and even scientific accuracy, when the game feels like it that is (*cough*lasers*cough*). Every segment on the mantis shrimps tail, every ridge on the spiny lobster, even the animations are impressively realistic. Its gameplay is fun and the class system is relatively (not perfectly by any means) balanced with some species having advantages over others or being better suited to different play styles.

My only real complaints would be that some classes need to be unlocked and the camera can be difficult to get used to. Even if I like a game I don't feel I'm enjoying it as much when I'm grinding painfully in order to unlock new classes. The camera changes on its own or manually refocuses when you hold Ctrl, but when you are near your opponent and/or the edge of the map it will automatically re-position itself which can be very confusing or tedious.

Oh right and the game about crustaceans (oh and anomalocaris of course) shooting lasers at each other does have some semblance of plot, or maybe it would be more appropriate to say lore? It was something about laser crabs and Wikipedia. But come on you'd buy it even if it had the plot of Terminator Salvation because I mean, it's friggin laser carbs man, if you don't want that I'm worried for you.

reviewText:
Gameplay Vid: http://youtu.be/iPOkZ1eTnIQ

Overall, I have to ask anyone who buys this game what they expect.  Do you expect to fight, claw and tail, for survival on the brutal, blood-stained silt of the sea floor?  Perhaps you think you'll find love as you swashbuckle your way through the annals of arthropod history?  Or do you thirst for power, like that of kings, so that you might rule over a mighty realm of crustacean citizenry?

Well, one out of three ain't bad, as they say.

Seriously, look at the game pictures and game trailers, and, most importantly, the NAME of the game.  If you buy this game, you know why you want it.

Personally, I had a LOT of fun playing this game, and I didn't even get very far yet.  Feel free to check out my gameplay footage on YouTube.

Despite being dated, the battles can feel very epic with lasers and bombs going off constantly.  I compare it to big mech anime for a reason.  Really, I almost think they wanted to make a cool space-based mech game but then could only program really clunky movement, so they redesigned the mechs to be slow crustaceans under water.

reviewText:
Neo Aquarium is basically a 3D fighting game. Only with crustaceans.
It progresses like your standard fighting game, pitting you against one major enemy in each stage until you work your way up to a boss. With a controller it's reasonably fun, and despite making very little sense the attacks quickly become intuitive. A variety of crustaceans makes for some extended replay value, but if you're like me you'll probably lose interest after beating the boss a couple of times.

The idea behind the game is completely insane, which makes it a lot more interesting than most fighting games.
There's a rough attempt at hanging a story on the gameplay, but it doesn't make much sense. While sometimes it seems like the intent is lost in translation, sometimes it comes through as funny and self-aware.

Controller support seems fully functional, at least with an Xbox One controller.

I'd pick this up if you're interested for anything under $7, depending on how much you like the premise. Much more than that and you'll probably feel like you didn't get your money's worth.

reviewText: Hands down one of the best games I have played this year. Unlike more recent games, NEO AQUARIUM -The King of Crustaceans- does not baby its players thus, creating an environment where the player must learn to survive through strategy and intuition.... true virtues of the Crustacean King himself. The game throws you right into the action to fend for yourself in the ocean's depths, which authentically illustrates what it is like for many crustaceans just after hatching and beginning their life as zooplankton before transcending into glorious armor plated behemoths. With biological authenticity and immersion ensured, put yourself in the lobsters shell... and go forth on a journey to experience the cycle of life -slaughter and consumption- and find what it truly means to be THE KING OF CRUSTACEANS.\n\nGO FORTH AND TASTE DESTINY

reviewText: I don't really play games like these, but I took a gamble on this and I was very suprised on how fun it is once you get the hang of it. Each creature is unique and has its natural predators and weaknesses.  You can unlock a variety of creatures and it really drives you to play more and more. The gameplay is pretty slow due to it being under what and some fights can seem exceedingly one-sided, but with practice you and rush through enemies that gave you a hard time in minutes instead of half an hour. The story is mostly in the beginning and in EX mode, and it is not much but this is not really focused on story anyway. For me this game has provided hours on entertainment and it is worth the cost. Anytime you are bored or have no internet and want to play offline, use this game.

reviewText: I've had this game off-Steam for a while. It may look weird at first, but it's actually a top-notch mecha game. With crabs.\n\nThe game is usually played by C"ommanding a bunch of sea critters that aid you in battle
date: while destroying or counter-commanding their critters. Destroying them gives you a power pickup which fills your POW meter and increases your maximum POW the next time you "S"hed. Then you hold down "X" to charge up a POW-drainign special.\n\nCorn barnacles drop the pickup all over the place
recommended: so if you have trouble fighting them... Just press "Ctrl" to toggle out of the camera lock-on
hoursPlayed: hold "Z" to lock onto those POW-dispensers
voteText: and either hold or mash "Z" (depending on your character) while side-stepping their shots. Shed into POW-3 and rip them apart.\n\nA possible con is that this game might have too much depth. Err

reviewText:
All of my what.

This game is reminisent of a Sega developed Dreamcast tech demo, down to the odd asthetics and design choices. It reminds me of an under water version Powerstone, but more unbalanced and kind of underdeveloped.

However, NEO Aquarium isn't a bad game, but it's not very good either. It's just kinda...there.

I WILL say it's a great game to stick in a Humble Bundle pack, I am not dissapointed with my purchace, this game is weird...but I like it. There is also humorously snide inspirational quotes between matches.

I'll give this game a solid HumbleBundle / 10

reviewText:
This is not a game for you if you want high levels of polish, fancy graphics or simple controls.

This IS a game for you if you want to be a barnacle and spawn a series of laser-silo barnacle friends to blast a lobster as it sheds its limbs to use them as drone weapons against you, then launch homing barnacle rockets at a crab as it uses it's own freshly-shed exoskeleton as a shield.

The game is completely ridiculous, a bit hard to understand, a bit cheap, but it's pretty fun once you understand sort of what you're doing and you can at least stumble through the campaign on Easy knowing only the basics.

I don't really mind the lack of polish, but the combat mechanics really could use more explaining, I'm really unsure how the AI pulls off a lot of the moves it does, especially those involving shed limbs. But it's easily $9 worth of dumb fun IMO.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
When I first saw this game on the Steam marketplace, I was excited to finally experience the true aquatic combat of Neo Aquarium.

The game places you in the shells of many underwater creatures that have their own unique and powerful abilities, including dislocating their own limbs to send them into combat and causing underwater whirlpools. You can even pick up ally and enemy sea critters and swing them around as you engage in whatever crustacean you are battling. I personally prefer to play as the Hermit crab since he has the 1-2 snail sync combo.

As you progress, you unlock a few new creatures to play as, including a Snow crab, an underwater diver and a Japanese waifu.

I was really excited to take my skills online, unfortunately, there are not enough Neo Aquarium fans online and I could not find one single opponent. The offline crabs will have to do.

This game gets a crab in a shell from me.

reviewText: neon genesis evanquarium
voteText: No ratings yet 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Pros:
-Awesomely goofy concept
-Entertaining attack styles and special moves
-Each character has their own quirks and playstyles
-Plays like a 1 on 1 mech fighting game, but with crustaceans

Cons:
-Tends to crash when a certain character uses their strongest attack (at least in my experience; other players report crashing at seemingly random intervals)
-Tutorial is nigh nonexistant and the manual is obtusely written, making learning the game more difficult than it needs to be
-Controls are clunky and take quite a bit of getting used to (using an XBOX360 controller is highly recommended)
-Multiplayer is as dead as dead can be, and the matchmaking is incredibly basic (no private lobbys, no dedicated servers, etc.)
